title-group.article-title: Medium- and high-frequency analysis of magnetorheological fluid dampers

article-meta.aff: 1BWI Group, Technical Center Krakow, Krakow, Poland

author-notes.corresp: Janusz Goldasz, BWI Group, Technical Center Krakow, ul. Podgorki Tynieckie 2, 30-399 Krakow, Poland Email: janusz.goldasz@bwigroup.com

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2011 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: Controllable dampers based on smart fluids contain internal passages through which the working fluid flows and wherein the controlled pressure drop occurs under the influence of magnetic or electric fields. In this paper, the dynamics of such dampers are analysed through a series of theoretical dynamic models of increasing detail and complexity. The models capture the medium- and high-frequency dynamics of the damping force output of the damper and include the lumped mass of the fluid contained in the internal flow passages, the piston and rod assembly mass, and the compressibility of the fluid and pressurized gas contained within the chambers of the damper. The models are derived in state-space form from which transfer functions and natural frequencies are obtained analytically and then calculated for each of the systems. The results are presented in the form of frequency responses (Bode plots). Finally, the effects of the key geometric parameters of the damper and of the relevant fluid properties on the damper force output dynamics are presented and discussed.

sec.title: 1. Introduction
sec.p: The purpose of this analysis is to develop a fundamental understanding of the medium- as well as high-frequency characteristics of hydraulic single-tube shock absorbers with pistons having annular flow paths. Such pistons are used within controllable dampers based on magnetorheological (MR) fluids.

The analysis also applies to electrorheological (ER) shock absorbers in the monotube configuration as well as other shock absorbers utilizing similar operating principles. Therefore, in this paper a series of dynamic models with different levels of complexity are created and analysed to better comprehend the dynamic phenomena that occur within such dampers. The authors identify the key design parameters, then examine their effects on the dynamics of the force output of these dampers.

To start with, certain configurations of hydraulic shock absorbers, namely MR and ER shock absorbers (Hopkins et al. 2001; Petek 1993) when subjected to a small-stroke, medium- or high-frequency excitation reveal unusual characteristics best described as a clockwise rotation of the force–displacement ellipses (‘football’ curves) with the stroking frequency (Alexandridis and Goldasz 2004; Nguyen and Choi 2009a; Peel et al. 1996; Sapinski 2006; Simms et al. 2000). This clockwise rotation is due to the phase shift that develops between shock absorber force and piston velocity (or displacement) at higher excitation frequencies. Within the same frequency regime, the phenomenon is virtually non-existent in conventional mechanical valve-based shock absorbers that operate on a different principle. In controlled dampers, and the MR shock absorbers in particular, the effect is clearly magnified by the relatively heavy fluid mass contained in a long flow path (annulus). Similar operating conditions are experienced by the fluid in controlled MR mounts (Nguyen 2009).

One hypothesis that was formulated in the early stages of the study through the analysis of existing damper models and inertia track models in passive engine mounts assumed the fluid inertia and compressibility to be the two most significant contributors in addition to the geometry of the annulus (Adiguna 2003; Ahmed et al. 1999; Kim et al. 1993; Lang 1977; Lee and Lee 2002; Mollica 1997; Singh et al. 1992).

In order to confirm it, a detailed analysis on the significance of the fluid inertia and the fluid compressibility was performed in the past using computational fluid dynamics (CFD) as well as analytical methods (Alexandridis and Goldasz 2004, 2005; Goldasz and Alexandridis 2007).

The purpose of the current study is to provide a systematic basis for understanding the phenomenon, to identify key parameters that influence the dynamic response of such shock absorbers, and to identify dynamically equivalent topologies. Aspects of the study can be useful for control studies as well as NVH (noise, vibration and harshness) analyses.

The present study deals with a series of almost self-explanatory case studies that, as the authors hope, should clarify the phenomenon. The authors proceed through a number of increasingly more detailed (and complex) models that include the lumped fluid inertia element as well as the piston and rod (P&R) inertia. Using the state-space representation of each system, they calculate natural frequencies and transfer functions for each system and identify the key parameters for them. Moreover, the authors point to functionally equivalent shock absorber configurations that can be analysed using the same equations of motion. Finally, they conclude the study with a simple engineering formula that can be used to estimate the phase shift between the damping force and the displacement input.

sec.title: 2. Dynamic models
sec.p:
In this section three different dynamic models of dampers are developed:
Model 1: This model describes the combined dynamics of the piston and rod mass and fluid ‘slug’ together as they bounce on two compliant columns of fluid. In this model, the floating piston and gas volume are neglected. Therefore, only the ‘symmetric’ (through-rod or double-sided) actuator is considered.
Model 2: Next, the authors develop a more realistic model by including the gas volume and the floating piston. This model is useful for investigating the effects of the gas pressure and volume on the frequency response of the monotube damper.
Model 3: This model is similar to Model 1, except that the motion of the piston is prescribed (to reflect real-life damper testing conditions).

In Models 1–2, an external force is prescribed to drive the motion of the piston. However, by convention, damper dynamic models use a prescribed stroke or a displacement input, thus eliminating the P&R mass effects (Lang 1977). In other words, the P&R mass is assumed to be part of the stroking actuator that supplies whatever force is necessary to generate a prescribed displacement profile.

Models 1 and 3 are not equivalent. However, the first (lowest) natural frequencies of the two models are the same, as shown later, since they represent the oscillations of the fluid ‘slug’ against the two compliant columns of fluid.
The analysis is focused on a piston configuration with one annulus in the flow path. However, it may be easily extended to the case of a piston with two and more annular flow paths in the piston.

sec.title: 2.1. Model 1: fluid and piston inertia dynamics
sec.p:
The damper model including the combined motion of the piston and the lumped fluid mass is shown in Figure 1. The model features a cylinder housing a symmetric piston assembly. Figure 1.
Model 1 layout; combined motion of the piston and the lumped fluid mass.

One equivalent configuration of the shock absorber is presented in Figure 2. In the alternative configuration the separating piston is driven by the external force, and the piston motion forces the fluid to flow through the stationary concentric gap between the cylinder and the inner ring. By inspection, it can be shown the above models are functionally equivalent. Figure 2.
Model 1 equivalent configuration; stationary annulus, moving piston.

The piston motion is driven by the external force F. The external-force-driven piston mass is M and its cross-sectional area is Ap. The volume flow rate through the annulus is Q. The pressure drop across the piston is ΔP = P1 − P2. Combining the P&R dynamics and the fluid ‘slug’ motion gives the following set of ordinary differential equations (ODEs) (1){-Q+Apv=1βV1P1·Q-Apv=1βV2P2·
Neglecting flow losses, the fluid ‘slug’ dynamics can be then described by the simple force balance equation: (2)ρLgQ·=(P1-P2)Ag

In a linear manner viscous flow losses can be included by assuming laminar flow through the piston: (3){ρLgQ·+RhQAg=(P1-P2)AgRh=12μLgbh3 where Rh denotes the hydraulic resistance (laminar flow through parallel plates or thin annulus), and Ag, Lg, b and h refer to the annulus area, annulus length, mean width and size, respectively. In order to meet the linear analysis constraints, the contribution of the MR (ER) effects is incorporated into the hydraulic resistance Rh. In that sense the resistance Rh can be interpreted as the equivalent linear resistance factor incorporating both the laminar viscous losses and the contribution of the ER/MR fluid's yield stress.
The dynamics of the fluid ‘slug’ has already been described by equation 3. To describe the P & R assembly motion in the presence of viscous losses, it follows that (4)Mv·+(P1-P2)(Ap-Ag)+RhAgQ=F

Assuming midstroke conditions (V1 = V2 = V0 = const), the equations can be re-arranged into a state-space form to yield (5)X·=AX+BF where X = [P1, P2, Q, v]T (6)A=[0 0-β1V1βApV10 0β1V2-βApV2AgρLg-AgρLg-RhAgρLg0-Ap-AgMAp-AgM-RhAgM0] and B = [0, 0, 0, 1/M]T.

In this case, the two transfer functions Hv and HQ are of interest. Accounting for the viscous losses makes the relevant equations rather lengthy; the authors opted to calculate the resulting transfer functions numerically. Briefly, assuming no viscous losses and Ap ≫ Ag, the transfer functions reduce to (7)Hv(s)=V(s)F(s)=[s2+2AgρLgβV0]1Ms[s2+2(AgρLgβV0+ApMβApV0)] (8)HQ(s)=Q(s)F(s)=2βApV0AgρLg1Ms[s2+2(AgρLgβV0+ApMβApV0)]

Finally, introduction of the symbols ΩM and ΩF leads to (9)Hv(s)=[s2+ΩF2]1Ms[s2+ΩM2+ΩF2] (10)HQ(s)=ΩF2ApMs[s2+ΩM2+ΩF2] where ΩM is the natural frequency of the solid piston bouncing on the two compliant columns of fluid, and ΩF refers to the natural frequency of the fluid ‘slug’ moving against the two compliant fluid volumes. They are as follows: (11)ΩM=2βMV0Ap2 (12)ΩF=2βV0AgρLg

In addition to that, the equations governing the motion of the piston mass and that of the fluid mass can be analysed in terms of the well-known single-degree-of-freedom system characteristics, namely, the resonant frequency, ΩF, the critical damping, ccr as well as the dimensionless damping ratio, ζg. By analogy, they can be defined as (13)mg=ρAg Lgc0=RhAg2kg=βAg2Vg ccr,g=2kgmgωg2=kgmg ζg=c0ccr,gV02VgΩF2=ωg22VgV0 BF=ωΩF
Using the final value theorem, it can be shown the model has the well-known steady-state solution of the following form: (14)F=vApRh(Ap-Ag)=12μLgbh3vApRh(Ap-Ag)

sec.title: 2.2. Model 2: asymmetric piston and rod and gas chamber
sec.p:
In Model 2, we introduce the rod (asymmetric configuration) and the gas chamber as shown in Figure 3. Again, the annulus is contained in the moving piston. Figure 4 reveals a shock absorber configuration that is equivalent to that introduced in Figure 3. Figure 3.
Model 2 layout; the asymmetric piston and rod and gas chamber. Figure 4.
Model 2 equivalent configuration; stationary annulus, moving piston.

Again, the piston motion is driven by the external force F. The P&R speed and the floating gas cup speed are v and v2, respectively. Similarly, the volume flow rate through the annulus is Q. The pressure drop across the piston is ΔP = P1 − P2. To obtain the ODEs describing the motions of the P&R assembly and the fluid ‘slug’, we proceed as follows.
Let (15)Vc=V2+V3
Differentiating the equation 15 with respect to time gives (16)Vc·=Apv=V2·+V3· since (17){V3·=-V3γP3P3·V2·=Q-V2βP2·
Neglecting the gas cup inertia yields P2 = P3, and the compression/rebound pressure variation can be expressed as follows: (18){P2·=βQ-ApvV2+βV3γP2P1·=β-Q+(Ap-Ar)vV1

Finally, the state-space form of the system (at midstroke conditions) is (19)X·=AX+BF where X = [P1, P2, Q, v]T and A=[0 0-βV1βAp-ArV10 0βV2+βV3γP2-βApV2+βV3γP3AgρLg-AgρLg-RhAgρLg0-Ap-Ar-AgMAp-AgM-RhAgM0] and B = [0, 0, 0, M−1]T.
Again, the transfer functions became fairly complex and lengthy, and the authors opted to evaluate them numerically. The results are presented in a later section.

sec.title: 2.3. Model 3: reduced-order dynamics, prescribed stroke
sec.p:
Preliminary calculations using either Model 1 or Model 2 indicated that the second of the two natural frequencies (due to the combined fluid mass and piston rod dynamics) is located far above the frequency range of normal interest. On the other hand, the authors desired to create a model that would be driven by a prescribed piston motion. Therefore, eliminating the fourth row and column of the matrix A reduces these systems to third-order. The resulting system is driven by the (prescribed) stroke (or velocity) input x(t) (or v(t)). The symmetric configuration of Model 3, corresponding to that of Model 1, is shown in Figure 5. Figure 5.
Model 3 layout; the reduced-order damper model with prescribed stroke.

As a result, the state-space representation takes the following form: (20)X·=AX+Bv where X = [P1, P2, Q]T, and (21)A=[0 0-βV10 0βV2AgρLg-AgρLg-RhAgρLg] (22)B=[0 0βApV10 0-βApV20 0 0] The output is the damping force Fd given by (23)Fd=(P1-P2)Ap
Again, assuming midstroke conditions (V1 = V2 = V0 = constant) leads to the transfer function of the following form: (24)Hv(s)=F(s)V(s)=2βAp2V0(s+AgρLgRh)s2+RhAgρLgs+2AgρLgβV0
Clearly, the reduced-order system is far easier to analyse. Again, the natural frequency is (25)ΩF=2βV0AgρLg

sec.title: 3. Simple estimate of the phase shift
sec.p:
In the simplest manner the effect of fluid inertia can be estimated by means of the inertia coefficient, Δ (N mm−1), which represents the slope of the major axis of the force–displacement curve as a function of the stroking frequency, ω (rad s−1) as shown in Figure 6. The coefficient Δ can be derived by examining the contribution of inertia forces to the damping force output. Figure 6.
Rotation of the force–displacement ellipse with the stroking frequency f; the grey lines of the slope Δ illustrate the ellipse rotation into the second and fourth quadrants of the phase planes, respectively.

To start with, assume that the inviscid force acting on the fluid volume in the annulus is Fa = −ρAgLgω2x = ΔPAg (the damping force is Fd = ΔP(Ap − Ar − Ag)). The relationship between the displacement of the fluid's lumped mass and that of the piston rod is x(Ap − Ar)/Ag. Therefore, the damping force can be given by (26)Fd=Δ(ω)x=-(Ap-Ar)(Ap-Ar-Ag)AgLgρω2x from which the simple estimate Δ(ω) can be deduced (27)Δ=-Lgρ(Ap-Ar)Ag[(Ap-Ar)-Ag]ω2

The coefficient is a function of the fluid density, stroking frequency, and actuator geometry (Alexandridis and Goldasz 2004). It describes the development of inertia forces inside a damper and is a fast engineering method of estimating them when sizing dampers for particular applications. The single parameter was found to predict the rotation angle of the force–displacement ellipse very well in the case of both experimental and simulated damper data in moderate frequencies of less than 30 Hz. Therefore, the presented inertia contribution can be useful for simple lumped parameter models of ER/MR dampers: a thorough review on parametric modelling of MR dampers was recently given by Wang et al. (2011). To complement the analysis, one exemplary application of the inertia components in such models of MR dampers is briefly outlined in the Appendix A.

The simple parameter, however, does not account for the impact of fluid compressibility (bulk modulus) which becomes important at higher frequencies. Therefore, more accurate parameters are needed as already explained in the previous sections.

sec.title: 4. Analysis and results
sec.p:
The following analysis is based on Models 1, 2 and 3. The numerical calculations are performed using the data of Table 1. The geometry and fluid data given in the table refer to a prototype MR shock absorber. Table 1.
Properties of a test MR damper
Symbol Description Value
μ Fluid viscosity, mPas 35.0
β Bulk modulus, MPa 100
ρ Fluid density, g cm−3 2.35
Ar Rod cross-section area, mm2 126.67
Ap Cylinder cross-section area, mm2 1662.0
h Annular gap, mm 1.0
Ag Annulus cross-section area, mm2 114.1
Lg Annulus length, mm 22.5
L1 Upper chamber length, mm 166.1
L2 Lower chamber length, mm 166.1
L3 Gas chamber length, mm 34.0
γ Gas constant 1.4
M Piston and Rod (P&R) total mass, kg 0.4

sec.title: 4.1. Model 1
sec.p:
The calculated results are presented in Figures 7 and 8 as Bode plots of the amplitude and the phase angle of the (complex) transfer functions plotted against the normalized frequency (ω/ΩF). Figure 7.
Hv-1: Model 1, amplitude versus non-dimensionalized frequency ω/ΩF. Figure 8.
Hv-1: Model 1, phase versus non-dimensionalized frequency ω/ΩF.

It is important to note how the numerical results on the transfer functions are presented. Traditionally, damper characteristics are defined as the force/velocity ratio. In Sections 2.1 and 2.2, respectively, however, the transfer functions Hv and HQ are derived as the velocity/force and the flow rate/force ratios, respectively. Therefore, the authors have calculated the amplitude and phase angle of the inverse quantities: Hv-1 and HQ-1 for Model 1 (as well as Model 2). However, only the inverse quantity Hv-1 is shown in the paper.

The dynamic characteristics depend on the flow resistance (Rh) which intuitively incorporates both laminar viscous losses and those due to the ER/MR effect (and the design parameters). Note the arrow on the graphs shows the increase in the flow resistance parameter.

An important observation comes from the phase plots: even for a very compliant fluid, the resonant frequencies are located far outside the 0–50 Hz region (or 0–0.3 in the normalized frequency terms). The phase shift, however, is significant even at low input frequencies and low levels of the flow resistance parameter (see Figure 8). Therefore, control over this particular characteristics (phase shift) seems far more important than specification and control of the resonant frequency.

Moreover, it is clear from the plots that the fluid characteristics dominate the low- (and medium-) frequency behavior. At a very high frequency (near and above the second resonance), both the amplitude and the phase angle become fairly independent of the hydraulic flow resistance. Such behavior is an additional motivation for transforming the Model 1 into Model 3 as described in previous sections.

sec.title: 4.2. Model 2
sec.p:
The calculated results are presented in Figures 9 and 10 as Bode plots of the amplitude and phase angle against the normalized excitation frequency, respectively. Again, the authors plotted the inverse quantity Hv-1. Examination of the transfer function plots reveals that the resonant frequency is altered by the presence of the gas chamber. It can be shown that in the limit the resonant frequency is decreased by 2 when compared with that of Model 1. The inclusion of the compliant gas chamber modifies the amplitude as well as the phase characteristics. That is due to the serial arrangement of the fluid volume below the piston and the pressurized gas volume that effectively results in a fluid volume of high compliance. In order to focus on the effects of the gas compliance on the damper dynamics, the authors ignored the static force generated by the gas spring (pressurized gas volume) by assuming a thin rod, Ap ≫ Ar. Figure 9.
Hv-1: Model 2, amplitude versus non-dimensionalized frequency ω/ΩF. Figure 10.
Hv-1: Model 2, phase versus non-dimensionalized frequency ω/ΩF.

sec.title: 4.3. Model 3
sec.p: The stroke-driven Model 3 is analysed and compared with the (symmetric) Model 1 described in Section 2.1. Note that the denominator in equation (24) and the numerator in equation (9) are identical. Thus, the two models share the same first resonant frequency, ΩF.

Here, the calculated results are illustrated in Figures 11 and 12 as Bode plots of the amplitude and the phase angle with the frequency, respectively. The input force frequency was again normalized with respect to the ‘slug’ natural frequency, ΩF. Comparing Figures 7 and 8 with Figures 11 and 12, it can be observed that the frequency responses calculated by means of Model 1 and Model 3 match well up to the first resonant frequency. Model 3 which is driven by a prescribed piston displacement (velocity) profile, ignores the (typically small) influence of the P&R mass on the frequency response within the frequency range from 0 to ΩF. Figure 11.
Hv: Model 3, amplitude versus non-dimensionalized frequency ω/ΩF. Figure 12.
Hv: Model 3, phase versus non-dimensionalized frequency ω/ΩF. Figure 13.
Force versus velocity: τ0 = 5 kPa, v0 = 0.26 m s−1.

sec.title: 5. Summary and conclusions
sec.p: The purpose of this study was to provide a systematic insight into dynamic phenomena occurring in certain shock absorber configurations.

In order to examine and illustrate the effects of the fluid inertia and compliance on the frequency response of MR/ER shock absorbers as well as other devices operating along similar principles (MR/ER engine mounts and the like), the authors performed a dynamic analysis of a series of dynamic models using linear state-space and frequency-domain techniques. The models utilize the information (geometry: damper body dimensions, annulus geometry; material properties: bulk modulus, density, viscosity and the like) that is available at the early stages of the design process. The results may allow for sizing of damper applications that operate at medium and high frequencies. The emphasis of this research was to identify factors influencing the output dynamics of such shock absorbers beyond the contribution of the yield stress in ER/MR fluids. Clearly, in ER/MR dampers the hydraulic resistance is composed of two distinct phenomena, namely, the viscous losses and the nonlinear ER/MR effect due to the field-induced yield stress in the fluid. In order to meet the constraints of the linear models, the authors investigated the effect of damping force on the dynamic characteristics by varying the hydraulic resistance Rh.
In addition, the simple estimate of the phase shift derived in Section 3 is a convenient way of illustrating the contribution of inertia forces in phenomenological models of MR dampers.

Based on these models and the underlying assumptions, the authors conclude that the role that the fluid inertia and fluid compliance play in dynamic behavior of MR dampers has been underestimated. These two fluid characteristics have been found to be the key contributors to the unusual behavior observed in experimental, small-stroke sine-sweep tests. Clearly, the high-frequency behavior of these devices may affect NVH characteristics of a vehicle. This aspect is beyond the scope of the present study. Although the resonant frequencies calculated for all models remain high, significant phase shifts are manifested even at low frequencies of damper operation and low damping coefficient levels in particular. To some extent, the damper frequency response can be upgraded using fluids of lower density and/or lower compliance. However, in MR fluids the yield stress depends on the amount of solid fraction in the fluid, and opportunities in reducing the fluid density are rather limited: the low density requirement would be detrimental to on-state performance of such fluids. Therefore, attention to the bulk modulus should be paid. Finally, some improvements in the device dynamic response (at high frequencies) can be made by careful selection of geometric design parameters as well as fluid properties.

ack.title: Acknowledgement
ack.p: The work was performed while the second author was Chief Engineer, Chassis Technologies, of Delphi Chassis Division (now BWI Group), Brighton, Michigan, USA.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This research received no specific grant from any funding agency in the public, commercial, or not-for-profit sectors.

sec.title: Appendix: On-state model of MR damper with fluid inertia
sec.p: To illustrate the application of inertial components in phenomenological models of smart dampers, the force balance equation of Model 3 is modified to incorporate the hydraulic losses due to the field-induced yield stress τ0 in the annulus. Then, equation (3) is rewritten in the following manner (28){ρLgQ·+ΔPcAg=(P1-P2)AgΔPc=2τ0hLatanh(aQ)+RhQ where ΔPc is the raw approximation of pressure losses across the active sections of the piston gap and any non-active portions of the annulus (La < Lg). The function tanh(·) is often employed for smoothing the force (pressure)–velocity (flow rate) characteristics at near zero velocities or flow rates (Simms et al. 2000; Wang et al. 2011), and the positive coefficient a is a smoothing parameter (to be estimated from real damper experimental data). In the absence of yield stress the above expression simply reduces to equation (3).

An exemplary simulation is presented in Figure 13. Using equations (1) and (28), the simulated data illustrate the model response when subjected to the sinusoidal velocity input v(t) = v0 sin(2πf0t + ϕ0) where f0 is the excitation frequency and ϕ0 denotes the phase. The examples were simulated using the data in Table 1, the yield stress of 5 kPa, and the smoothing coefficient a equal to 5000.

The example shows the increase in the hysteresis width with the increasing frequency as well as vibrations of fluid's lumped mass at piston motion reversal points. The increase in the damping force output (due to the inertia forces) with the excitation frequency can be observed as well.
